On 1/20/06, Elliotte Harold <elharo@...> wrote:
>
> C=C3=A9dric=
 Beust =E2=99=94 wrote:
>
> > A typical example is Web tests:  what's the p=
oint of running a hundred
> tests
> > exercising servlets if the Web server=
 failed to start?  It also helps
> for
> > the diagnostic:  instead of tell=
ing the user "101 tests failed", you can
> > tell them "1 test failed, 100 =
tests were skipped".
> >
>
> I disagree. I occasionally do something stupid=
 like that that breaks all
> or nearly all of my tests. Seeing that 90%+ of=
 the tests are failing is
> a *huge* clue as to exactly what's going wrong.=
 It keeps me from wasting
> time looking for small bugs in one class as I m=
ight do if only the first
> test failed.


I would argue that you are still=
 wasting time since the report gives you 100
tests to choose from, which is=
 a bit silly since it knows *exactly* which
one failed and *exactly* which =
ones were skipped.

Why would you prefer to read "101 tests failed" over "1=
 test failed, 100
tests skipped"?

--
C=C3=A9dric
